Award.AwardTitle: Transforming Agriculture and Natural Resource Management Education to keep up with the Changing Industry

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This project improves the Plant Bioscience Technician (PBT) program at Leeward Community College (LCC), which serves as a model program for technicians in the diversified agriculture industry. The project contributes to a well-educated workforce for the emerging diversified agriculture and natural resource management sectors in Hawaii. In order to revitalize and make the learning experience more relevant, more links to industry are made in the classroom, and a Living Laboratory supports various courses within the program. The Living Laboratory supports the Introduction to Plant Sciences, Introduction to Horticulture and Plant Propagation, and Integrated Pest Management courses. Online courses are being developed as part of the PBT program, and will be available to all who are interested in this model program for educating technicians in diversified agriculture and natural resources. In addition, a public outreach campaign informs the general public, high school teachers and students, and adults searching for a career change, about the growing agriculture industries and related career opportunities in Hawaii.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this ATE project was to develop the Leeward Community College (Leeward CC) Plant Bioscience Technician (PBT) program into an excellent model program for technicians in the diversified agriculture industry, in an effort to increase the number of students entering the agriculture and natural resources career fields and improve their training. During the lifetime of this project, the following major accomplishments were achieved:

1. The Academic Subject Certificate (ASC) in Plant Bioscience Technology (PBT) was approved and officially included in the Leeward CC curriculum. In Fall 2013, The Academic Subject Certificate (ASC) in Plant Bioscience Technology was renamed to ASC in Plant Biology and Tropical Agriculture.

2. A new two-year AS degree in Plant Biology and Tropical Agriculture was created with support from the ATE grant. The new AS degree also includes two stackable certificates, Certificate of Competence (CO) and Certificate of Achievement (CA). The program was jointly proposed by two University of Hawaii Community Colleges, Leeward CC and Kauai CC. The UH Board of Regents approved the new degree at both campuses effective Fall 2014. 

3. The following 11 PBT courses, all new to Leeward CC curriculum were approved and taught during the lifetime of this grant. These courses include:

  • PBT 100.  Orientation to Hawaii's Agriculture Industry (1 credit lecture)
  • PBT 122. Soil Technology (3 credit lecture)
  • PBT 141 Integrated Pest Management (2 credit lecture, 1 credit lab)
  • PBT 197 Experimental course for the permanent course PBT 122 (3 credits)
  • PBT 198 Experimental course for the permanent course PBT 269 (3 credits)
  • PBT 200 Introduction to Plant Science (3 credit lecture)
  • PBT 200L Introduction to Plant Science Lab (1 credit lab)
  • PBT 210. Introduction to Environmental?Science (3 credit lecture)
  • PBT 250. Tropical Landscapes (3 credit lecture)
  • PBT 251 Sustainable Crop Production (3 credit).
  • PBT 264 Introduction to Horticulture and Plant Propagation (2 credit lecture, 1 credit lab).
  • PBT 275 Introduction to Crop Improvement (3 credit lecture, 1 credit lab)
  • PBT 290B/C/D/E Plant Bio Sci Tech Internship.

4. The Living Laboratory, a field site, was created to offer experiential learning space for students in plant sciences and related activities. The field site provides students with a location to manage personal gardens and carry out field trials as part of classes and extra-curricular activities.

5. PBT 100 was developed into online courses, and is available to all who are interested in this model for training technicians in diversified agriculture and natural resources.

6. Growing our Talent www.ctahr.hawaii.edu/growingourtalent/ website was designed to have a fun, engaging and approachable feel while being packed with basic information about college options and career pathways. Growing our Talent provides information about agricultural related college degrees from Leeward Community College and University of Hawaii, Manoa – CTAHR.

7. The total number of students enrolled in PBT courses rose from eight new students in the 2010-2011 school year, to 68 in Fall 2015, which is a 750% increase in enrollment during the lifetime of this grant. 

8. Total 19 students received AA, AS or ASNS degree in Plant Bioscience Technology (PBT)

 


Last Modified: 10/29/2015
Modified by: Anna M Wieczorek
